issue.title: Deprecated behaviour
issue.body:
~~~
Using a single directory for all classes from a source set. This behaviour has been deprecated and is scheduled to be removed in Gradle 5.0
	at Build_gradle.<init>(build.gradle.kts:55)
~~~

this is in yggdrasil-maven-plugin. Fix is probably to let sourceSet have default classes dir, and copy from there instead of redirecting to target/classes.

body:
Thanks for bringing this to our attention.

I've added it to the general backlog for the time being.

rename.from: Gradle plugin uses deprecated gradle api.
rename.to: Gradle plugin uses API that is deprecated in Gradle 4.0

issue.title: Upgrade to Gradle 4.0

body: @erikhakansson can you please look at #873 -- I don't see the deprecation warnings you posted here. Do I need to set an option/flag when running Gradle to get the deprecation warnings?

I guess you already fixed it in your commit
https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/pull/873/files#diff-9aa77cd7dadba00b2b057304763c811cR96

Found a single deprecation warning when upgrading to 4.0-rc-2:
```
> Configure project :documentation
Evaluating project ':documentation' using build file 'C:\Dev\Github\junit-team\junit5\documentation\documentation.gradle'.
[Asciidoctor] asciidoctorj: 1.5.3.2
[Asciidoctor] asciidoctorj-groovy-dsl: 1.0.0.preview2
Gradle now uses separate output directories for each JVM language, but this build assumes a single directory for all classes from a source set. This behaviour has been deprecated and is scheduled to be removed in Gradle 5.0
```

rename.from: Gradle plugin uses API that is deprecated in Gradle 4.0

body:
Sorry for not getting back to you. I've been away. I'll try to have a look at it this evening. But as @thiagogcm mentioned, it looks like my issue should be solved by your previous commit.

I'll report back!

No problem!

Only a single warning is left: somewhere in the `documentation` project...

> Configure project :documentation
Gradle now uses separate output directories for each JVM language, but this build assumes a single directory for all classes from a source set. This behaviour has been deprecated and is scheduled to be removed in Gradle 5.0
